title: Ossie Lovelock
text:
Oswald Ifould Lovelock (28 August 1911 – 1 August 1981) was an Australian sportsman and sports administrator. He represented Western Australia at <a href="cricket">cricket</a> and baseball, and also played <a href="Australian%20rules%20football">football</a> for in the <a href="West%20Australian%20National%20Football%20League">West Australian National Football League</a> (WANFL). In later life, he took up golf, winning several tournaments at clubs in Western Australia, and went on to serve as president of the <a href="Subiaco%20Football%20Club">Subiaco Football Club</a>.
Career.
Born to Oswald Oliver Lovelock and his wife, Rose Janey (née Ifould), in <a href="Highgate%2C%20Western%20Australia">Highgate</a> on 28 August 1911, Lovelock played both cricket and football from an early age, representing Western Australia at a national schoolboys' carnival in 1926. He debuted for West Perth in the WANFL in 1932, and played in the club's 1932 premiership win. In total, he played 25 games for the club over three seasons from 1932 to 1934, kicking three goals, and also spent time with the club's reserve team in the West Australian National Football Association (WANFA).
He made his cricket debut for <a href="Western%20Australia%20cricket%20team">Western Australia</a> in October 1932, against the <a href="English%20cricket%20team%20in%20Australia%20in%201932%E2%80%9333">touring MCC side</a>, making 14 <a href="not%20out">not out</a> and recording two <a href="stumping">stumping</a>s. He played another match six days later, this time for an <a href="Australian%20national%20cricket%20team">Australian XI</a>, featuring players such as <a href="Vic%20Richardson">Vic Richardson</a>, <a href="Jack%20Fingleton">Jack Fingleton</a> and <a href="Don%20Bradman">Don Bradman</a>. He was Western Australia's first choice <a href="wicket-keeper">wicket-keeper</a> throughout most of the 1930s, and served as vice-captain to <a href="Richard%20Bryant%20%28Western%20Australia%20cricketer%29">Dick Bryant</a> in most matches, captaining the side for one game against the MCC in 1936 when Bryant was unavailable. He played one match for a <a href="Western%20Australia%20Combined%20XI">Western Australia Combined XI</a> in 1936, featuring <a href="Jack%20Badcock">Jack Badcock</a>, <a href="Stan%20McCabe">Stan McCabe</a> and <a href="Clarrie%20Grimmett">Clarrie Grimmett</a> In total, Lovelock played over 100 matches for West Perth and North Perth in the <a href="Western%20Australian%20Grade%20Cricket">WACA District</a> competition, making several <a href="century%20%28cricket%29">centuries</a> and captaining both clubs. As was common amongst Australian cricketers at the time, Lovelock played baseball during the winter to keep fit. A member of the Ramblers club in the <a href="Baseball%20WA">Western Australia Baseball League</a>, he played in the position of <a href="catcher">catcher</a>, and was selected in the state team for Western Australia's first interstate match, against Victoria in September 19336.
In 1940, Lovelock was transferred first to <a href="Victoria%20%28Australia%29">Victoria</a> for his job, where he played for Essendon in the <a href="Victorian%20Premier%20Cricket">Victorian Premier Cricket</a> competition. In 1941, he was again transferred, to <a href="Tasmania">Tasmania</a>, where he played for <a href="New%20Town%20Cricket%20Club">New Town</a> in the <a href="Tasmanian%20Grade%20Cricket">TCA Grade Cricket</a> competition. Returning to Western Australia in 1950, he took up golf, competing in several tournaments, and winning one, a <a href="stableford">stableford</a> event held at <a href="Yokine%2C%20Western%20Australia">Yokine</a>. In 1951, he was elected to a position on the executive committee of the <a href="Western%20Australian%20Cricket%20Association">Western Australian Cricket Association</a>. In 1952, he was appointed president of the <a href="Subiaco%20Football%20Club">Subiaco Football Club</a>.
